column4: hello, i am gentoo user, helping out a guy with ubuntu - is there a way how to compile a kernel? i mean, specific?
for ubuntu? cause gentoo does it differently... thanks
Make sure build-essential has been installed, then google "Compile Ubuntu Kernel" and it should pop you up ..
How is Gentoo doing? I used it exclusively until I got lazy .. :) .. I miss it though ..
i know how to compile kernel, but, i usually do it without initramd (gentoo way).
With Ubuntu out of the box it's lacking the tools needed to compile. sudo aptitude install build-essential (might have misspelled it) .. contains the items needed to compile.
i was debian user, never used ubuntu, but i got dissatisfied with constant overwriting of your confs - like, /boot/grub/menu.lst
gentoo at least warns you when it overwrites your configs :)

what was it in Gentoo .. um .. etc-config or something? I miss it, it was nice, but my server's got really hard to keep up .. I'm no good at compiling kernels in Ubuntu, but you should be able to find it via Google or the Ubuntuforums.org site ..
etc-update, yeah :) i found the command, it's make-kpkg...
it's actually the same as debian way. Though init ramdisks suck, it's useless hassle, in my opinion...
I'll have to try to compile a Kernel in *buntu some day .. I'm hoping after classes this semester I can install Gentoo on one of my many boxes and get back to my roots ..
well, i had custom kernel in debian, along with custom scripts - then apt-get dist-upgrade smashed it all
what you don't like about apt-get?!?
apt-get seems to mess stuff up for me more than aptitude ..
that's weird. because aptitude USES apt-get.
especially when removing things I installed with aptitude .. aptitude seems to keep an eye on dependancies better when it is used for installation .. emerge however is still my fave ..lol
